Tastes pretty nice, more dehydrated banana with chocolate and roast coffee, nutty notes, vanilla, and some metallic notes. Carbonation is decent. This beer is an interesting mix of sweet and bitter. I like it.

500 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours dark, dark brown, with reddish tinge.  Pours thick tan coured head, leaving good lacing.  Carbonation is large sized bubbles.  Aroma is sweet, malty.  Flavour is strong roasted malt, hint of coffee.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2015 Heavy bitterness that didnt seem to be countered by anything else. The sourness came through for me too. Not a bad beer but just not right for me to want more . Rerate June 2015- still that bitter finish but nowhere near as strong as last time so upped it a wee bit. Actually grows on me as I down pint. Better as if warms . Maybe served too cold

Pours mahogany with a nice huge and chunky tan head that has good retention and leaves some really nice lacing. Aroma is sweet malt, earthy hops, some spices, wet grass and a little stale coffee. Flavor is roast, coffee, a little apple, earth, spices, lots of burnt sugar, caramel, an almost milk like sweetness. FInish is dry and earthy with some roast, a little bitterness.

500ml bottle from the LCBO
Pours a reddish brown with a small tan head good lacing all the way down
The aroma is malty and herbal quite nice
the taste is a bit thin with good slightly bitter malts

The beer pours a brick red/brown colour with a thin slightly off white head. The aroma is pretty thin, mostly malts, some metallic notes. The flavour is decent, medium bitter bite, with a malt base of light caramel. All and all a highly drinkable beer, with some a fair amount of flavour, but pretty uninteresting to be anything special.
Aroma is kind of roasty.  Color dark and cloudy.  Nice frothy head.  Taste is heavy bitterness, medium sour.  Full body with thick texture.  Long finish
Nice aroma of flowers and grass. A summery beer in flavour with fresh cut grass being dominant. It also has a long malty finish.

Date: November 01, 2008
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Cellar Party
Appearance: clear dark red, fine beige head, bits of lace
Aroma: sweet malt aroma with a nice fruity character, light earthyness
Flavor: flavor starts off dry, touch of caramel sweetness kicks in and brings some fruityness, earthyness grabs hold to dry it back out again, hint of dry chocolate, light bitter finish

A dark brown ale with a creamy, light beige head. Mainly malty aromas including caramel and berries along with a roasted malt backdrop. A sweet flavour profile; subtly chocolatey, a touch fruity and more roasted malt tones. A predominantly dry malty bitter finish with perhaps a whisper of hoppiness. Sweet and roasted throughout and a fair palate texture.

Look away, and its effervescent head might well vanish. Smells like a home-brew shop but is drinkable due to the inclusion of alcohol.

[edit - just tipped this!]

Bouteille de 500 ml. Nos yeux observent une bière de couleur cuivrée-rougeâtre et un col de mousse modeste. Au nez on découvre des arômes de chocolat, de sucre brun, de cerises noires et de fruits dans l’alcool. En bouche le corps est moyen avec une effervescence moyenne. La bière possède un arrière goût d’enfer (chocolat, cerises noires et café) le tout complété par une bonne dose de houblon.

Dark brown pour with vivacious white head. Aroma is rich with caramel, biscuit, and roast. Flavor is rich- sugary caramel and molasses with a slight balancing roasty flavor. Palate is smooth and thick. Decent offering.

Appearance: Pours a clear, chestnut brown body with a bubbly, whitish head.

Smell: Fairly fruity nose smelling of raisins, berries, and sherry-soaked bananas, with further notes of dark caramel and, to a lesser degree, roasted malts.

Taste: Dark maltiness yields a taste of caramel and tiny bits of roast and chocolate. Brown sugar sweetness throughout. All of the previous fruits from the aroma. Perceived wood hint. Spicy British hops provide a light, cleansing bitterness. Finishes dry and fruity.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. The medium-low carbonation makes for a smooth mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Fairly enjoyable and worth trying!

500ml bottle.  medium brown color, thin tan head.  Aroma of butter toffee,  rich sweet malt extract and a bit of toast, and age.  Flavor has a bit of roast, some nutty character, burnt sugars. Lots of roast and a bit of smokiness.   Light bodied.  I could drink a pint or two while enjoying the evening news.

From a brown bottle - Pours dark brown with almost no head or carbonation.  Smells of sweet caramelized malts with lust a tad of light hops.  First sip is very sweet with caramel notes and very little hops.   Finishes with a welcome bitterness. Well under carbonated. Not much happening here.  Worth skipping this one!

A pleasant, mild ale that is delightfully creamy and malty much like porter. Good carbonation and coffee and nut flavors are highlights. Not a life-changing experience but very drinkable and satisfying nevertheless. Overall, good.

Darkest of red/brown colours biege head good carbonation.Aroma malty,sweetness.Flavour strong maltiness,vanilla ,hops nice citric bitter,a creaminess to the lips,fairly good body and lasting tastes at the finish.
chocolate malty smell. dark colour with medium creamy head. strong malty flavour with fruity after taste. one of my favourite beers,
Drak brown with a low head. Malty aroma with lotøs of berries and earth. The flavour starts out sweet with notes of caramel and cafe latte and goes into a grassy hop ending.
Had an aroma of coffee, chocolate and malt. It was a mahogany colour with a small white head. Had a strong malty taste mixed with treacle it was slightly fizzy in the mouth.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2008 Taste 7/8 Bottle. Looks: Brown/black cherry with nice lacing cream head. Aroma: 1st grain. 2nd yeast/must/sour. 3rd sugar caramel. Taste: Medium bodied, nice sour and malt flavor.  Chocolate, roasted malt. Toasted. Creamy and quite yeasty.

Amber-Ruby.
Big creamy head.
Aroma: Roasted malt, fruits.
Flavor: Fruits, burnt malts.
Burnt finish. 
OVERRATED!
Perhaps I got a bad bottle but it was more than "roasted", it was the most burnt beer I have ever had.
500 ml bottle. brown ruby colour. taste is like roasted coffee. fruit is not really notisable.
Bottle. Roasted/toasted aroma, dark fruits, even those are toasted. Flavor the same, gets a bit dull. Mouthfeel rather thin, especially for the roasted character presented. Ok.

Deep red-brown appearance with medium carbonation and a thick, long-lasting head worthy of a stout. Aroma is pleasing, with bready malts followed by lots of toffee, floral hops and even a little lemon. Taste is in excellent balance, with lightly roasted malts mixing with assertive hops and pepper notes. Full, creamy, extremely smooth mouthfeel. Nice.

Bottle.  Pours a clear copper with a frothy tan head.  Aroma of toast, roasted/burnt malt, light blackberry jam and butter.  Flavor of roasted malt (burnt, crisp toast).  This is roasty, but has a thin, light body.  Slight bitterness in the finish.  Interesting beer, enjoyable.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2014 Appearance: Dark redish brown. Nice amount of head. Longlasting.
Aroma: Malt and fruit.
Taste: Malty. Dry. Bit of fruit. Bitter aftertaste. Prunes. Coffee-ish.
Info: 500ml bottle, 1/10-2006, 102/500, 5/300M
UPDATED: JAN 11, 2009 a reddish amber roasty malt with weak palate ...didnt take proper notes on this one but it wasnt so memorable
..an acquired taste.....intense liquorice/coffee notes......wel lkept in bottle....nice label....worth trying

(England)  This ale has a  dark amber color with a med-white head. The aroma is of berries, roasted nuts, and caramel. This brew has a flavor of  dark fruit / coffee / spices / and a slight dry finish, There is some nice lacing too !!!  Overall i feel this very refreshing and worth a try.

Pours chestnut brown with a nice, vreamy beige head.  Aroma of roasted nuts, toast, and dried apricots.  Flavor isnt as rich as the aroma suggests.  Slightlty toasty, with a subtle fruitiness.  Mildly bitter, dry finish.  Somewhat thin.

Tasted 26/05/2008. 500ml bottle from Regional Wines and Spirits.  Reddish chestnut with a light tan head. Bright. Raisin toast, brown sugar and caramel on the nose. A hint of port royal tobacco. Toasty malt and dark crystal-malt fruit in the mouth. A little clena is about my only real criticism. Hard water finish, with a light tickle of hop bitterness. more toast and a light acidity. Very nice drop, without the x-factor of a 4+.
Pours a dark ruby brown with a tan head.  Aroma of sweet molasses and raisins.  Taste is mildly roasted and sweet with a bitter finish.  Not bad.
Dark amber with an off-white head. Roasted malts dominate the aroma. Smooth amd seet on the palate with a dry finish. I enjoyed this one, but its missing just a little something.

50 cL bottle. Pours dark brown with a redish glare and  a semi creamy off-white head. Light roasted malt aroma with a light coffee-ish note. Flavour is roasted malt and coffee with a light liqourice edge from the hops. Nicely balanced and with just enough sweetness to counter balance the roasted profile. Light coffee-ish finish mixed with liqourice. Dry bitterness in the far finish. Nice one.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown colour to a, thin head. Smells like berries, and ha an appealing earthyness. Roasted coffee in the finish. I have to say Ihis beer is not for me.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2012 [16/11/2007 - 500ml bottle from Asda, High Wycombe] Very very bitter indeed; in fact the bitterness put me off initially.  However, then I finished it and really really wanted another, yet I couldnt explain why. Its dangerously drinkable for a beer of this strength.  

[18/1/2012 - re-rate, 500ml bottle from Maureen & Dave - cheers!] This was one of my very early rates, so I was glad to be given the opportunity to re-rate it (especially given the disparity between my low original rating and the site average).  It pours a chestnut brown with a moderate creamy head and fizz clinging to the sides of the glass.  As the appearance suggests, it is a little too fizzy in the mouth for the style.  Theres a vinous hint in the initial taste, followed by a little chocolate, but the whole thing is pervaded by the bitter metallic taste of over-enthusiastic pasteurisation.  A little dryness in the finish, but also a bit sticky. Still didnt like it, and this time I really didnt want another one.

Pours dark amber with light tan head. Roasted malt and chocolate aromas. Flavors of roasted malts. Finishes dry with a slight hop taste. Medium to full body with moderate carbonation and a slick mouthfeel.

The scent is not particularly strong, of course I do have a cold. I can detect aromas of floral hops, a little musty basment smell, and some sweetness. I genuinley think this is one of the nicest beers to look at that Ive ever seen, the head is huge and rocky, and long lasting leaving a great lace. The color is a beautiful deep ruby red. The taste is complex, and very nice. There are strong bitter hop flavors from the start. Im sure this isnt barell aged, becuase generally breweries boast that from the start, but there is a fantasic oaky flavor in this beer. Notes of coffee, cherries, and dried fruit follow through to the back of the tongue. For all of its flavor this beer is well rounded, but in no way is does it have a "huge" flavor, it would be very nice as a session beer. The palate is sharp on the front of the tongue but smooth towards the back. One of my very favorite english ales.

Bottle on 4/15/2008. Deep amber brown with a medium rocky tan head and some sticky lace. Caramel, brown sugar, roasted nuts and a dark fruitiness waft up from the glass, an inviting beginning. Smooth medium body with a complementary light effervescence, and a soft dry palate combine for a nice mouthfeel. Flavors of burnt sugar and spicy hops balance well. Theres a sharp bitterness at the finish, but not at all objectionable.
I wasnt expect much of this, but was a belter.  Quite hoppy and bitter - some sweetness and a bit nutty.  Very drinkable.

Bottle- pours deep brown. tan beige head. smells barnyardy earthy sweet sugar and some nut. quite well balanced. very nutty. and a dry finish. chocolate and toast. the hops give a good earthy tone to everything. better than expected.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2008 500 ml bottle, bogth in Cardiff by my neighbour Kjetil - thanks for sharing. Brown color, small off-white head. Aroma is sweet malt. Flavor is caramel and roasted malt with some hoppy bitterness.

Pours a lovely colour, Very dark red. It smells nutty, then bready. Its malty, evidently alcoholic,  It tastes of roast malt and barley, creamy, a dark berry fruit note. I imagine id love this on cask.

Bottle. High creamy and lasting off-white head. Clear dark brown body. Pretty complex aroma of berries cocoa hops and alcohol plus roasted malt. Relatively hoppy berries flavor in combination with roasted malt. Low carbonation. Short aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Bottle, courtesy Tony at Oldsmar Tap House. Pours a dark ruby red, with a soapy fluffy head. Caramel aroma, licorice, big malt. Big caramel flavors, toffee, maple syrup, and a nice lingering licorice bite. Again, caramel in the aftertaste. Good finish. Bitter, smooth-bodied. Enjoyable.

aroma of malts and bananas. brown body with some carbonation w/ a small light brown head. taste of malts ,roasted nuts, a bit of coffee and yeast. palate is the only thing that bugs me about it as it is a bit hoppy on the finish. this is a good winter beer. 
               ...on a side note, let this one warm up a bit before drinking. Much better as it gets warmer.

500ml bottle 
5.7% ABV 
I tried this beer on February 11, 2008 after purchasing from my local LCBO outlet.  The beer poured a translucent reddish brown into the glass with a thick, creamy, off-white head that lingered.  The aroma is primarily malt with a little skunkiness.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied, creamy, with some carbonation.  The flavour is also malty, very English.

A deep dark translucent brown with a thick moka head. Aroma of brown sugar, butterscotch, and plums. In mouth, a smoky oily malt, with light sweetness, and light British hopping, with nice sustained nuttyness. Medium bodied. Bottle is actually almost a year old, from Capflu if I recall (so from BC) and still a good quaffer.

500mL bottle purchased from LCBO in Toronto.  Pours a clear dark brown.  The aroma is lemony - perhaps a bit metallic.  Flavour is a balanced maltiness and of a decent strength.  Its all decent stuff, I suppose, but Im finding it a bit boring really.  I suppose its just not my style.

Brown bottle, 500 ml, purchased at the LCBO, savoured on February 16 2008; eye: light ruby, clear, slight effervescence, voluminous beige head, no lacing; nose: hops, light alcohol, light malt, light caramel; mouth: a bit thin, carbonation, grainy malt covered by grainy hops, caramel, finale in grainy malt-hop, average astringency, mildly bitter, lightly sweet, medium body; overall: quite enjoyable

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 500 ml, achetée à la LCBO	, savourée le 16 février 2008; il : rubis léger, claire, très légère effervescence, mousse beige abondante, pas de dentelle; nez : houblon, léger alcool, léger malt, léger caramel; bouche : un peu mince, carbonatation, malt granuleux recouvert de houblon granuleux, caramel, finale en malt-houblon granuleux, astringence moyenne, moyennement amère, légèrement sucrée, corps moyen; en résumé : bien aimé

Bottle. Dark brown with some red in it, white head. Roasted malt with low bitterness. Caramel? Quite dry. When it was warmed up a bit the malt really was there but still not much hops in it.  No rubber notes that can be present in a ale.

This dark brown and amber coffee ale looked fairly subdued in my glass with a quickly disappearing head. Its aroma of malt and hops was slight, but I attributed that to it being colder than needed for serving. The flavor seemed to balance well between the malts, water, and hops so I decided to wait for it to warm up. Twenty minutes later, it came to life with a maltier taste than I expected. It turned out to be a good ale for me.

Clear dark copper/golden poor with a frothy light brown head.  Aromas of banana nut bread, bubble gum, alcohol, roasted malts and sweet caramel.  Fantastic, greatly balanced mouthfeel... first impression was WOW.  Great bitter mouthfeel that completes the creamy caramel sweetness perfectly.  Flavors are mostly what you get out of the aromas.  Medium to full body for an almost 6% beer thats great.  Crisp hoppy finish, i wasnt expecting much, but i am more than satisfied with this brew.

500ml bottle - An old ale?  Really?  I thought it tasted like another bitter and a good one at that.  The aroma is mostly malt, but the flavor has a nice balance of lightly roasted malt and crisp hops bitterness.  Its medium bodied and finishes dry.

Bouteille de 500 ml, acheté le 12/01/08 au LCBO de Rideau et King Edward (Ottawa). Belle rousse, petit collet avec un peu de dentelle. Arome légé dhoublon et de caramel roti. Gout de malte fumé, avec une touche de cacao, sensasion dhoublon légèrement amère, finition fruité.

Bottle - 500ml. Dark copper body with average carbonation and a decent off-white frothy head. Well balanced malty/hoppy aroma with roasty hints. Sharp hoppy taste that ends with a long bitter finish. Nice example of English Altbier.
Dark redish brown.  First impresion is sweet.  But much more coplex than that.  An earthy taste.  Medium malts.  Almost like a very mild porter.

Pours dark reddish brown, off white creamy head.  Nice sweet roasted aroma-malty finishes with a bit of a bitterness.  Worth a try if you like these darker Ales.  You might be "rigged" if you swill enough of this!

500 ml bottle. pours dark redish brown with a medium off white head that lasts and lasts. lotsa carbonation that settles down throughout. aromas are peaty malts, some nuttiness, but mostly just malty. flavours are similar with hops showing at the end. well put together, not mindblowing or life changing but id never turn one down. could drink it in session.

(Bottle) Pours a brown color with a tan head. Aroma of smoky malts and yeast. Taste includes a fair amount of peat, grains, and nutty malts. Light hop notes towards the end. Sweet finish as well. Good mouthfeel, but the palate was a touch thin. Nevertheless, I really enjoyed this beer.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2009 [1021-20070131] 500mL (w/ jerc). Old wet hay hints in aroma also indicates alcoholic grains. Clear, dark dark red brown body with a big foamy off-white head. Grainy malt flavour has hint of alcoholic earth wood. Medium body. Fair. (5/4/6/3/11) 2.9

[1995B-20090213] 500mL bottle. Wet wood toasted malt aroma with mild chocolate hints throughout. Clear, dark amber body with a long-lasting creamy off-white head. Rich creamy wood chocolate malt flavour with a long sweet malt aftertaste. Medium-full body. Great texture, great depth. (7/4/7/5/15) 3.8
(c/o a friend, w/ him, jerc)
1pt Bottle:  Poured a dark brown with a thick.. thick head.  Scent is malty.  Big aftertaste that just makes you want to have another drink.
Wow Big head. Bubble texture. Creamy Rich smoky flavor. Mouthful is sweet and biter at the same time and it leaves this bubbly feeling when its gone

Brown color, with a beige head, leaving laces, toasty malt nose, with a hint of malt roastiness, some nutty, toffee accents, with a subtle fruity aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a toasty, nutty character, with some mild roasted coffee bean and toffeeish flavors, with a faint peppery floral hop note, leading towards a malty, leafy, minty hop bitterness finish.

Bottle from the LCBO- Pours a mahogony/deep brown liquid beneath a foamy beige froth. Nice lace and retention. Milk chocolate and yeast are the main aromas, some fruit, a touch of roasted malts, brown sugar. Pretty sweet and malty, some good chocolate flavours, coffee, kinda nutty sweet. Finishes a touch thin and probably a little too sweet for me.
Bottle at parents house. hay, grass, brown, cloudy, aminimal head, medium bitterness, medium body, soft carbonation,

Bottle. Awesome deep scarlet/brown appearance. Aromas of cocoa powder and toffee. Average coffee-ish flavour gets more intense towards the middle, with an accompanying swell of chocolate, then finishes poorly into a watery palate. Bigger would have been better.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2009 2009-02-05. Brown body with a modest khaki head. (3+) Interesting aroma, light metallic notes over dry malt, earthy notes. (6+) Similar flavour, dry malt with light bitterness, finishes very lightly astringent. Earthy character. Average plus palate. Decent but I am not sure it is one I would return to. 6+/3/6/3/14 Bottle from LCBO
Jan 2008. Bottle from the LCBO. Dark amber tinged brown body with a good sized pillowy off white head. (4+) Dusty, toasty malt aroma of scorched caramel, earthy undertones. Similar flavour with an earthy chestnut character, malty, toffee sweetness with moderate malty base. Something odd about the overall impression is off putting to me. It grows on me as the glass goes on but I just cant really get into it. Smooth slightly fuller than average palate. Slight grabby astringency at the back of the throat. Well crafted but not really to my tastes. 6/5/6/3/13 - 3.3
This is a bit of awright, innit? Tons of burnt, chocolatey malts in the nose and flavour, some licorice, fruity notes and perhaps bread. Very trad porter, like a lighter and sweeter Guinness.

Very nice malty aroma, dark brown - cola like - with a bit of toffee.  

My only complaint was with the aftertaste - some hops, but a bit of an unusual kick that made me think that this particular bottle might have been a bit "overripe".

Tasted in Toronto.  Tasted in a dimpled mug. Obtained from LCBO as part of their winter warmers series 2007.  Pours with a deep reddish colour, clear, with a medium white foamy head.  Aroma is slightly sweet, toffee, caramel.  Some notes of alcohol in the scent also.   Flavour is more muted and subtle than the aroma.  Fairly bitter, ends with a hint of sweetness.  Fairly rich and full bodied.

I think the sheep (ram) on my bottle wants a belly rub, my wife thinks its dead and that I shouldnt drink this beer.  Nice thick dark tan head, that really lasts.... and lasts... and okay I will come back when the head has faded enough for me to take a sip...first we check the scent though... Coffee, toffee, caramel and raisins.  Nice dark thick flavour.  A lot of smoked flavour.  Nice and softly dark.  Roasted nuts, and meats.  Very nice.  My one complaint is that the taste lingers and will tarnish future rates and flavours.  A nice beer, a little darker then I personally enjoy but still very nice.

This ale poured a deep red colour with a big foamy tan coloured head. To the nose you can get scents of caramel, butter, slightly smoked malt, coffee and a little cocoa. First taste is very smooth with flavours of roasted malts with caramel and a little coffee. The finish is a little bit hoppy with a bitter flavour lingering. Very Good!

500ml Bottle: Pours deep brown, big beige head.  An aroma of sweetness, bread, banana, and muted hops.  The flavour is nice, good feel in the mouth as its only lightly carbonated and goes down smoothly.  Lots more hops bounce off the sweet and roasty malts for a great blend, and the the yeast taste comes forward along with a little chocolate.  Good beer to go with a great label!

Dark amber brown with minimal head.  Smells a tad malty and roasted.  Tastes a bit fruity and malty, strange combo, but seems to work.  Again you get that roasted malts taste.  It does have a dry and slightly bitter finish.
Very heavy coffee and black licorice flavor; dry and a bit of hoppiness.  Slow pour has an off-white head, and an aroma of black licorice and coffee.  All around earthy with hops.  Not my favorite.

Bottle: Poured an amber color ale with an off-white foamy head with good retention and some good lacing. Aroma consists of notes of caramel with some dry malt. Taste is a nice mix between some dry malt with some subtle notes of caramel and what I believe to be a Fuggles hops ending. Average body with some medium carbonation. Well done and easy to drink.

500ml bottle - pours a deep brown/auburn shade with a nice big off-white head. The aroma is sweet and fruity with a lot of malt with hints of chocolate and caramel. The flavour brings the latter two notes out a lot more and theres a good amount of roasty malt and chocolate at the top which then moves over for a dryer, hoppy finish. The fruitier notes mingle well with the earthier ones. Some smoke as well. Very nice.
dark brwon amber color, some off white head, nose is alot of malts, balanced malt and hops kinda stale flavor, decent beer not a fav but good

500 mL bottle from LCBO, served at cellar temp. in a tulip glass. DE07/07.
App.:  Deep copper, clear, fair white head.
  
Aroma:  Dark chocolate, milk chocolate, black coffee (med. roast), light funk, light resinous hops, a bit nutty and earthy.
  
Palate:  Medium body and soft effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Much like the nose, a little earthier, a little nuttier; dry with a touch of bitterness.

Drinkable.  Not a style that I love.

dark ruby color, small head, that dissapeared very quickly. Aroma is vey malty, lots of caramel, and some faint hops. Flavour is very malty, and bready, with some grains. Nice bitter finish, not sure why this is an old ale, to me its more of a strong english bitter. The hops really come through in the finish.

Bottle from the LCBO. Too much malt for me in both the aroma and taste. Other flavours include caramel and coffee. The palate is fine, smooth and full-bodied, with a bitter finish. I went to school in Yorkshire, so I wanted to like this, but I guess I should stick to my Timothy Taylors.

Bottle. Pours a clear, bubbly, deep orange-copper with a large foamy off-white head. Aroma of lightly roasted caramel malt, nuts, fruit and a hint of smoke. Flavours even better, with lightly roasted malt, nuts, fruit and hops. Dry, lightly smoky, bitter finish. Medium to full bodied. Not what I think of off the top of my head when it comes to an Old Ale, its almost Porter-like, but its still a very good and complex beer.

500 mL bottle.  This beer is dark, dark brown.  Medium-sized, thick, sticky, persistent head.  Aroma is malty, caramel sweet, dusty, with coffee grounds and a little spice.  Taste is caramel sweet, balanced by black coffee, roasted malt, and bitter hops.  Nicely bitter finish.  Smooth.  Full body.  Medium to low carbonation.  Nice beer.

500ml bottle, 5.7% a/v

Pours a deep mahogony with a thick tan head. Aromas consist of hops, fruit (bananas?) and yeast. The flavour is roasted malt, black coffee, bitter chocolate, and a slight hint of red wine. The finish is clean and dry and the mouthfeel is generous without being overpowering. Nice winter ale.
Pours a dark copper. Good malt presence, but well balanced by the hops. Lightly bitter finish. Very easy drinking ale for a winters day.

500ml bottle. Pours a deep dark mahogany colour, with a large beige head. Aroma: really nice roasted malts, a touch of hops, but really just nice roasty malts. It smells really good actually. Taste: All malt, starts off with some coffee/caramel, then roastyness, followed by a touch of smoke. Very sweet, with a slightly dry finish. Its almost like a schwarzbier to be honest, with a touch more sweetness and slightly less dryness. For something only at 5.7% abv, it actually seems to have an alcoholic kick to it, which is a bit odd. Over-all a very nicely put together brew, I love the roasted malts, its been a while since Ive had something like this.

500 mL bottle.  Malty aroma of molasses with a hint of coffee.  Pours a clear dark brwn with a frothy off-white head.  Flavour is very nice and malty, the mildly sweet molasses and coffee coming out again.  Finish is a moderate bitterness.  A very enjoyable winter beer.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2007 500 ml bottle - pours a deep chestnut with a two-finger off-white head.  Very nice aromas of hazelnut, plum, earthy hops and some alcohol.  Flavour filled with roasty malt with an undercurrent of sourness as well.  Some warming alcohol at the back of the throat.  Very soft in the mouth with a chalky and bitter finish.  Exceptionally well-made old ale.

Large foamy off white head. Malt and molasses smell with a medium body. The mild sweet malt flavor is a little overwhelmed by the bitter and its not all that bitter. Still it’s a nice beer and I like that the head was still there at the last drink.

Bottle.  Nice dark copper, medium tight foamy head.  Nice nutty, smoke, malt aroma. Great foamy medium mouthfeel.  Good taste - very roasty with some hops, especially in finish.  Almost smooth and very drinkable.  Complex.  Excellent strong/old English ale.

500ml bottle:

Pours a deep chestnut ale with shimmering ruby highlights in the glass. Decent sticky 2 finger cap..lasts, laces well.

Aroma: Figs, cocoa, earthy tones

Flavor: Rich, malty, some complexity of dried fruits-nuts-aromatic tobacco-cocoa, lush earthyness....finish is drying, and lightly bitter with some black malt astringency.

A very nice strong which hides its alcohol has a silky mouth feel and is both drinkable and satisfying
bottle.. great head from the pour.  nice dark espresso brown color.  smells strong with a hint of brandy. very full and strong taste, but with a little bitter bite at the end. smooth after taste.
Bottle Very dark maroon pour with great creamy head. Aroma of roasted malt and a brandyish hint. Slightly more complex flavor, more roasted malt and a bit of hop.

Bottle.  Poured a dark red, with a finger of head.  Very sweet and fruity nose.  Tastes amazing.  Very sweet initially, followed by a very sweet dry chocolate finish.  Very smooth and finishes exceptionally.  Great lacing.  The chocolate finish is delayed on my palate almost perfectly.  One of the few beers I find myself savoring and being disappointed when the bottle is empty.  Highly recommended.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2008 An excellent old ale, this reminds me of a lighter, more lively and flowery Old Peculier or a lighter, complex porter. It is very dark red brown with a big, thick, dense tan head and some lacing.  The aroma is rich, toasty caramelly malt.  The taste is a little earthy, chocolaty, caramelly malt, coffee, all mild, and toasty (not burnt), and some flowery, bitter hop character.  It is smooth with a sweet and bitter finish.  Its lively, complex, smooth, and tasty.
Poured Amber with amazing head.  This one was a little too carbinated, which I dont normally like.  It had a good flavor to it though.
Poured an amber color with a good sized head. Would have gotten higher marks but,  little too much carbonation for my taste. Just a little bitter during the aftertaste.

0.5 L bottle, bbe Oct 07. Clear red-brown topped with a moderately sized off-white froth. Nose of bitter chocolate with nuts and coffee liqueur. Roasted malts dominate the taste but there is also some hop bitterness. Lingering bitter aftertaste. Light tartness, succulent body.

1 pt 0.9 fl oz. bottle: L73 22:29.  Pours a deep ruby-brown with a generous creamy tan head.  The malty aroma is both pleasing and overwhelming.  Medium mouth feel.  Strong flavor and dry finish.  A good brew.

500ml bottle @ Cardinal. Clear brown/red body with a medium beige head. Aroma is caramel malt, slightly roasted and some prunes. Flavor is balanced and very pleasant, roasted malt, caramel, dry fruit and liquorices. Quite well bodied and a good bitter finish.

Brown...actually looks like a pepsi with less carbonation, tan head...I smell rich malts, caramel-like...and sweet and like candy...molasses on the palate, quite pungent balanced well with just a touch of bitterness on the finish...over ripe bitter bananas...refreshing texture, leaves a taste that encourages to keep on sippin

Bottle. Dark ruby/brown with dissipating head. Fruity aroma with some metal. Creamy taste of toffee, butter and malt with a touch of fruity sourness. Dry finish of raisins, almost like a drier trappist.
Bottle from ASDA. Dark brown with a decent off-white head. Red fruit and toffee aroma. Flavour of fruity malt with some earthy hops and a long dry finish. Very good.

16.9 oz- bottle.  Big head, was expecting a Youngs Special London color, but it was much darker.  Sweet aroma- cherries?  Flavor was complex- it was a combo of a scottish smokiness, some hops of a bitter, and the chocolate of a porter.  Really unique- had it with some smoked oysters- made my Fiday night.
Excellent brew.  Malty, bready, delicious.  This beer is unique and well worth the price.

Pours dark copper-black with a thick foamy head; almost like a stout, except strangely clear. Apples, caramel and raisins in the scent. Flavor is more herbal than fruity. Oregano, hops, and perhaps a hint of cherry. Very soft mouthfeel, especially on the lips. Kinda buttery, and not so much oily. Rather enjoyable overall.
very decent, incredibly biscuity, malty and bitter. Some raisins and nuts, some wheat. Very tasty and decent but something a bit out of the norm. Very interesting nonetheless

Pours a medium-dark copper-brown with a thick head and great lacing. Nearly unnoticeable aroma - slightly fresh and sweet but too subtle. Flavour is enticing - biscuity, dark and lightly toasted, buttery and with a balanced sweetness & bitterness. Hops are there but they dont follow through to the finish, which is brief and dry and slightly spicy (think Chinese 5-spice). Body is creamy and well carbonated. This is not an exceptional beer, but it is certainly a drinkable one. Would go very well with fish & chips.
Deep dark brown color with a disappearing head.  Beautiful malt aroma of chocolate cherrries and coffee.  Spicy taste with alot of bitterness for an English ale.  Medium body with soft mouthfeel.

500 ml bottle from Country Club liquors; nose of fig newtons, vanilla, and caramel malt; rusty cherry color with a medium beige head; flavor has light fruitiness, hop bitterness, and the finish is the hops. Decent old ale, would be a good session brew except for the $4.49 cost!

1pt 9oz bottle bought at Bayville Package Store, Selbyville, DE...pours reddish-brown in color with a sudsy light beige head...sweet smell of malt, dark fruits...taste was sharp, bittersweet, yet semi-dry with a bit of alcohol in the aftertaste...medium mouthfeel...this is a really good ale, too bad I only bought one...reminds me of a lighter Old Foghorn that I also have in my fridge.
4/10/05 500ml light mahogany with large off-white head. Nutty sweet malt tastes.  Good contrasting with hops. very light for an old ale.

Dark copper hue. Small reducing head. Strong nose of malt, alcohol and raisins. Luscious mouthfeel of malt and raisins, plum and hop. Nicely balanced with some hop. Low carbonation. Reminds me of a Barley Wine. A very good drink.
Pale brown; lingering amber head.  Earth, straw, wheat, carob in aroma.  Rich body of carob, molassas, hops, wood, some smokiness, pepper, cheap coffee, with a bitter dry finish.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2007 The Riggwelter is an excellent example of its style. The beer pours with a soft head that lingers with lace patterns on the glass. the inviting arome is filled with black current and grape notes. A deep brownish-red hue cries out to you to drink the beer. The entry is rather big: malty, roasty, and smokey but also smooth with no sharp edges. Aftertaste lingers delectably in the back of the tongue, and the mouthfeel is delightful. More-ish for sure.
Character galore in this one. I loved it from the first dark, full-bodied sip. A fine English ale.

Bottle -- Pours a light brown with no visibile carbonation and a huge frothy beige head with some retention and heaps of lacing. Quite a subtle aroma of roasted malt with a little bit of, perhaps, banana and fruit. Slightly watery mouthfeel. Flavour is a treat, with lots of roasted malt, stewed fruit and some bitterness near the end. A nicely balanced drop.

Exceptional nose of bubblegum & figs, some sulpher at first, wheat, raisins, fruit & flowers.  A whole lot goin on here.  The brew pous a sparkling ruby with copper highlights.  The majestic cascade resolves into a massive off-white, tight & creamy head that is fully lasting and leaves great lace.  The brew has a floral front, a sweet middle, and a finish that is big on raisins and coffee.  In a word; WOW!  The full body is creamy and soft.  The finish feels dry.  This beer perfectly illustrates why I would never return home if I ventured to the U.K.!!
Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with an off-white head. Sweet malty roasted aroma. Sweet roasted malty flavor with caramel hints. Sweet malty roasted finish with a slightly bitter aftertaste.

bottle. Clear and dark colour, medium-sized head. Aroma of hops, coffee and wild berries. Hoppy flavours dominate, solid malty background with hints of wild berries and coffee. Short finish but pleasant aftertaste.

500 ml. bottle (dusty and old looking, but from a distributors cool and dark garage). Poured a ruddy dark clear brown with a cream colored/light beige frothy head. Aromas of dark roast malts, bruised apples and bananas, cask oak and/or old cabinet wood, cellar, raisin, cranberry and/or oxidized red wine.  Flavor of toffee malt with a dose of vinous and raisiny essence,  sweet grains, plums, and feathery hops in the back.  Sturdy full body. One of those generally widely available imports that Ive passed by until now. Nicely "classic" tasting Olde English ale.
From my fall 2006 notebook.  Dark brown color with heavy malty nose and a roasted character.  Malt and hops in the body with a good finish.
Bit like a full bodied porter, really. Nice roastiness and pronounced hops with some acidity in the aftertaste.

Dark brown ale with a fruity, malt aroma.  This pour had a smallish tan head, yet created some nice lacing.  Very smooth mouthfeel, with clear hops and good malt flavor, with some licorice.  Finish is a balance of malt and hop.

Reddich-brown with a fair-sized off-white head.  Roasted malt, caramel, and banana in the nose, with some straw.  Taste was a ton of straw, popcorn, and bitter, bitter malt.  The straw is nearly overwhelming when you get to the bottom.
500 mL bottle.  Reddish copper with creamy white head.  Caramel, slightly fruity, malty aroma.  Sweet malty taste with some bitterness and a roasty finish.

The color was a deep red/amber.  The head was creamy, light beige, foamy, and laced a little.  The aroma resembled a musty basement a little.  The flavor was some roast, must, and a little waxy.  The palate was thin/medium bodied.  The finish was a little waxy.

Nice dark brown color with a huge head. The aroma is malty and quite alluring and the flavour is very malty and full with notes of roasted malt, at hint of coffee and caramel and the hops gives a nice bitterness all the way through the flavour. Nice and full mouth feel. Perfect for the dark months of winter.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2008 500 mL, stamped 02,05,06. Dark brown-ruby  with a large, lasting head. Aroma is barely present. Maybe some chocolate, raisin, and red wine. Maybe. Flavor is raisins, toasted nut, red wine, earthy wood, toffee, some slight coffee. Palate is very smooth and medium-bodied, with a drying finish. Complex balance of flavors here. It seemed to sweeten up after allowing it to "breathe" for about 10 minutes.

Bottle at home. Fantastic ale. Dark brown colour with wheaty, fruity nose. Really nice with roast malt taste, comprised of rich myriad flavors, including wheat, caramel, hazel nut, chocolate, chesnut and honey. Also prickly with a honey taste and bitter finish. Very good.

Clear bown body with an attractive foamy white head on top.  Banana and light roast malt in the aroma.  The flavor has a core of dry pale and chocolate malt with the finish leaving you with a blend of roast malt, yeast fruit and hop bittering.  Good soft mouthfeel.

Pours a deep mahogany color w/ a medium, semi creamy froth. Hangtime is good w/ full, sticky lacing. Aroma of mild cocoa. Medium nectar w/ ample (mucho) residual effers. This brew posseses a defined dark cocoa character. A mild roast component creates a nice roasted coffee bean flavor. The sweetness factor is NIL. The malts are bittered and balanced right out of the bull pen.  Its very sessionable and I wish I had more. The finish is bittered perfectly.

A fine strong ale. The aroma is simply stunning - malt, hops, nutty and a hint of coffee. Pours a deep reddish brown with a tan head. Lovely flavours - again, the malt and hops shine through, with subtle background tastes (coffee, nutty). Smooth on the palate with lingering tastes. Overall, a fine nutty brown elixir. Serve at or slightly below room temperature.

Dark mahogany colour; good imitation of a B.C."H.". Caramel, a bit of old portwine, chocolate biscuit, and just a perception of smokiness. Roasted tastes, even dark, bitterish malts, in the end again a bit  smoked. Subtily hopped, especially in the finish. Excellent MF, for such a modest ale. Chewy, near viscous. A very nice, tasteful Yorkshire ale. May I pray for a bottle-conditioned version?

Poured a dark copper brown, but remained translucent and thin. The aroma was a little cornish/basement sour, slight malty aroma. the flavor was thin and sweet with a slight smokey character. Crisply carbonated palate. An ok beer.

Bottle. Mahogny with a nice tan head. Good malty nose with chocolate, earth and some roast. Rich chocolate flavours with a dry roasted finish. Had expected a fuller body. Highly complex and enjoyable.

Bottle from Morrissons, Banbury 20-04-07. Pours a ruby colour and has a good fruity and malty nose, good malty and full bodied beer some sweetness but strength whilst apparent isnt overpowering. Nicely bittered and all in all thoroughly decent beer.

Pours with a reddish transparency and creamy tan head. Richly malty nose with a hint of mandarin hop leafiness. Smoothly creamy mouthfeel. Pungent lingering bitterness and smooth, slatey maltiness. Hints of chocolate and caramel. No-nonsense Yorkshire abruptness in the finish. A tasty brew, but one is plenty enough.

Bottle. Dark ruby colour with a tan head. Roasty aroma with notes of cheese, blackcurrants & liquorice. Roasty, dry flavour with notes of hops, coffee & plums. Medium body with a soft carbonation. Nice complex beer.

(50 cl bottle form Systembolaget) Clear dark red color, big lasting fluffy tan head. Sweet and hoppy scent, also a bit chocolate. Sweet, roasted malt and hops taste. Coffee and roasted malt aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.
Nice bittery ale with chocolate and caramel hints.  Good hop and malt flavour.  From a bottle at Woodmans.

Huge creamy tan head, dark chocolaty brown with ruby highlights. Flowery hops in initial aroma quickly overtaken by liquorice and dark, well roasted malt. Goes down smooth and rich, dry bitter taste but very drinkable - like a decent stout but less chewy. Very very good.

Bottle. Dark clear copper with medium fluffy off-white head. Smooth fruity malt aroma, slightly roasted, with earthy hops. Maybe I can sense some bananas. medium to full bodied and very smooth. Very dry and bitter, but pleasant, finish.

This had a good ,but quickly dissolving head.Color a luscious red-brown.Aroma was a rather subdued  caramel malt.It has a complex flavor of biting sweet caramel malt and active sour mash.finishes with somewhat bitter hops and barley.I guess I taste some bananas,as stated in the commercial description,but I didnt notice it until I read about it.Has a pretty good ,somewhat sticky palate.This beer is underrated.

Poured a deep drak reddish brown with a frothy head. Sweet aroma with hints of chocolate and something I cant put my finger on. Flavor has a distinct English Ale bite to it but overall a very nice ale.
Excellent beer. Pours really smooth with nice frothy head. Appearance is nice and dark. Taste is tremendous and smooth on the pallet. Highly recommended if you have an opportunity.
i found it a bit lacking on aroma. wonderful depth of flavor, with serious hints of blackberry and fruits followed by rich malts. smooth, dry, non-lingering finish.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2014 Bottled.  A very dark brown coloured beer with a tan puddle for a head.  The aroma has caramel, chocolate and boozy dark fruit.  The taste has dusty chocolate and caramel.  Decent alcohol.  A little smoky character comes through also.  A decent Old Peculier-a-like, and easily Black Sheeps best beer.  Score 3.6Subsequent ratings scored 3.6 and 3.5.  Average unaltered
A dark red / brown colour with creamy off-white head.  Malty, black berry aroma.  Flavour is quite roasty with hints of black berries and mild hops.  Has a medium body with a mild bitter finish.

Drinkable dark ale with a pleasing dark color and smooth taste.  Reviewers go on about the rich aroma but I found it rather meager.  Multiple flavors are claimed by others that I cant detect.  To be honest, I find the ales name and humorous explanation of Riggwelter more interesting than the ale itself.

Brownish red hue tan head with good lacing.  I found the aroma to be a little disappoiniting on this brew maybe i had a bad bottle, but there was a cough syrup presance to the aroma.  Flavor was a little better some astringent notes but othewise had a nice balance between carame and earth malts, finishing with a  nice hop finish.

Aroma of lightly toasted malt - aka caramel? Reddish copper color with a vigorous beige head that laces a bit. Starts with coffee and dark fruit, followed by toasted/roasted malt flavor. Light fruit flavor and a bit of bitterness for the finish. Not astringently dry, but not overly malty sweet either. Good one from Masham. Ripon? Isnt that about 10 miles away?
bottle: nice clear nut brown colour, with not much head. light aroma of caramelly malts. flavour is malty and kinda sweet, with a chocolatenees. nice soft bitter finish.

Clear light brown, not much tan froth.  Mild malt aroma.  Very malty and caramelly flavor, with some chocolate and a semi-dry finish.  Very bready/yeasty.  Fuller-bodied than it looks and overall a bit like a brown ale or oktoberfest.

Pours a bright mahogany into an English pint.  Tight tan micro head with excellent retention leaves slight lacing as it slowly recedes.  Funky coffee aromas. Creamy with alcohol-filled chocolate flavors front to back.

Pours dark brown with reddish hues and a small, foamy tan head. Aroma of English toffee malt, brown malt, sweet plummy malt. Taste is complex, manages to incorporate elements of chocolate, toffee, vinous malt reminiscient of cherry. Notes of smoke, pepper, and vanilla. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with lush, foamy carbonation. Such subtletly! A well crafted ale.

Bottle. Pours reddish mahogany with beige head. The aroma is pruney with some caramel and a faint hint of honey. The flavor is prune, caramel, and alcohol with a bitter chocolate and raisin finish. Not bad... this was something Ive been putting off trying for a while, but Im glad I finally did.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2007 I love this beer hoppy nutty and maltly. Hope to find this on tap one day. Rerate on tap at the brewery fucking amazing. Page 61 of MJs Great Beer Guide and only 462 Classic Brews to go.

500ml bottle from Rons in Farmington.  Somewhat translucent dark brown body with ruby-red highlights and a little under an inch of head that leaves great lacing.  Smells like roasted malt with kind of a fruity banana quality to it.  Tastes sweet with toasty malt and hints of banana.  Flavor is very rich and complex.  Body is on the heavier side of medium-bodied, somewhat creamy.  Fairly drinkable, though this one is a bit of a sipper IMO.  Very impressed - looking forward to more beers from this brewery!

Bottled version pours a reddish brown and sports a towering fluffy beige head with great lacing. The aroma has notes of raisin, butter, and cherries, and is quite strong compared to the flavor. The falvor mirrors the aroma, but is soft and subdued ending in a tart and slightly bitter finish. Good creaminess, even from a bottle.

(Bottle) Pours nutty brown to red. Light roasted, buttery aroma with milk chocolate/nougat, fruits and bananas. Small notes of roseleaf, soft fudge and sweet liquorice. Roasted flavour with some coffee and dark chocolate notes. Salty and light bitter finish. Medium body.

Black/brown, clear, with a good sized tan head. Weak nose, with a bit of a charred note, some diacetyl seemingly, a touch of tamari sauce. Quite bitter in flavor, with buttery toast notes, a hint of malt sweetness.

Bouteille de 500 ml achetée à chez ANBL (Dieppe, N-B). Arôme: Odeur de caramel et de chocolat. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée foncée avec une moyenne densité de bulle. Présence dun moyen col crémeux avec une large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel brûlé et de chocolat. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement crémeuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence de malt torréfié en arrière goût. (Rating #818)
Nice dark color, creamy head. Sweet aroma. Flavor was a little sweet and chocolatey, also creamy. Smooth finish as well. I thought it was ok.

500 ml bottle. Dark ruby red and a hint of brown. Throws a tall creamy light brown head. Lightly sweet nose and a distant roastiness. Dark caramel and chocolate. Crisp bitterness at first. Then more malty flavours and a clean chocolate flavour. Surprisingly bitter. A really nice dark strong ale, but this one clearly not a session ale as it is too roasted and too potent.
Great full bodied beer, dark and slighty creamy. Decent head on this beer. was vey impressed.

nice pour, head could be a bit more though.  pours dark brown, close to black.  fuller-bodied beer.  caramel creme nose, mixed with light hops and strong malts.  taste follows, also chocolate malts with a coffe and bittersweet delicately balanced smooth finish.
Very dark amber, moderate head, decent lacing. Aroma brings spicy hops, caramel, chocolate, earth. Medium bodied, enjoyable for the style.

Bottle: a rich clear chestnut colour with a thick and creamy caramel coloured head; a bitter aroma with traces of coffee and boiled cabbage; thinner in the mouth than expected, with roast malt flavours and then a strong bitter burnt aftertaste. A pwerful beer that makes its presence felt, but rather one-dimensional.
Enjoyed in a 16.9 oz bottle at the movies.  Slight roastiness, medium to full body Ale delights the palate.  A little too watery for me but it is definately a great brew for the flicks.
Dark amber with heavy off-white head. Malty and flovery hop notes. Medium to fuill body with a bitter aftertaste.

Bottle 50cl. Poured dark amber red, with a thick and lasting off-white head. Malty, bitter coffee aroma. Prominient hops and malt with a floral taste of caramel and roast nuts. You are left with a strong bitter aftertaste, a little astringent. Thick, oily and chewy palate.  Quality winter ale.
Great English Ale. Nice head. Distinctive malt flavor - smooth finish. Flavor is excellent - caramel and toffee hints.

Bottle.
Clear red brown coloured with a huge off white head.
Aroma of malts, caramel and fruits.
Flavour of malts, fruits, caramel and hops.
Hoppy finish.

Bottle pours dark amber with a big creamy offwhite head that stays very well and laces the glass in weblike patterns.  Aromas of toasted malts, caramel, and maybe even a touch of toffee.  Flavor is good caramel, toffee, toasted malts, a touch of bannana, and some light hops on the finish.  Good soft creamy mouthfeel.  Well carbonated.  This is pretty drinkable and certainly worth a try.

Rich deep amber pour.   The nose is all roasted malt and a dried fruity highlight.   Flavors of roasted malt, caramel, dried fruits, light touch of alcohol.   The palate is fairly light with a decent amount of carbonation.    Pleasant straight-forward brew, especially warming as the fall weather begins to draw near.

Poured from the bottle, a strong clear brown colour with a large beige rocky head with some good lacing. A rich, sweet malty aroma with hints of nutmeg spice. Rich earthy malt flavours with a smooth mouthfeel at first, though the finish is a little rough.

shallow head.  bitter and spicy on the initial taste, but hops do not linger long.  sweet malty-caramel flavour.  some depth. for colour - approaches dark.  probably wont make you overturn (velte) on your back (rygg) as the Old Norse name implies.

On the palate it isnt powerful and moving, but it does give a somewhat smooth, sweet, and deep flavor. And overall, that is enough for me to enjoy it. It wont take a place among my all time favorites, but it is worth trying for the smooth flavor in itself. And on a total sidenote, the cap has a cool design I thought (I collect them).
Bottle. Dark. Very roasty malts with a dry hoppy bite. Seriously malt dominated. Liked this very much.
Clear redwood colour a thin lasting creamy off-white head, aroma is malty and liquoricey with similar tastes but with a hoppy finish.

Pours tan with a creamy white head.  Juicy, fruity aroma and taste.  Some bubblegum.  Maybe it was just the bottle I had (or maybe it was just me) but there was this weird, plastic aftertaste.  Regardless, it was a good way to start the evening.
Bottle. Clear amber coloured with a small off white head. Aroma of malts, tobacco, caramel, fruits and yeast. Flavour of malts, fruits and yeast. Hoppy finish.
Dark black in color with a foamy light brown head. Thick malt, coffee sweet aroma. Spicy bitter first flavor ended sweet and rich caramel.

Bottle.  Attractive translucent mahogany pour, big fluffy tannish head.  Big malty, toffee laced nose.  Light roasty flavor edged with more caramel, earthy notes....pretty good.  Medium bodied, fairly smooth.  Appropriate bitterness throughout and to the end.  Nice.

Faint, faint flowers in the aroma. Some fruits... maybe peach? Looks dark, exactly like the bottle it arrived in (empty). The head disappears quickly. The taste has a wonderful mix of sweet and bitter. It starts as an eruption of barley, faints to some flowery flavours in the middle and finishes strong and bitter in what seems to be liqurice. Very bubbly. Session beer.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2006 From bottle. Strong sweet liquorice aroma. The ale is clear, good carbonation with a nice frothy head. Cola in colour. Nice bitterness with a sweet texture that blends lovely. Tangy aftertaste, a little malty to. A nice stong ale. Cant go wrong with Black Sheep I find.
Pouring this Ale into a glass was a treat.  The dark red-brown topped with a creamy head is a sight to see!  The taste was sweet and roasted; and a great balance between the bitter and yeast tastes.

1/2 liter bottle.  Poured a jewel red brown of polished mahogany with an impressive off-white creamy head and superb lacing.  The best looking beer Ive poured in some time.  Aroma is sweet and moderately malty, lightly hopped, light doughy yeast, some honey, and banana bread.  Flavor is full of lovely sweet malt with a finely crafted balance of bitter and yeasty notes.  Some brown sugar.  Finish is medium long and light-to-medium bitter with pronounced caramel flavors.  Medium carbonation, medium body, smooth and creamy mouthfeel.  This was the perfect picture of an English ale.  I had this years ago at the brewery, but forgot about it until I saw it on a trip to California.  I really wish I could get my hands on a few more of these.  I could easily drink this by the gallon.  One of the best!

Its really one of my favorites. This ale had a great chocolatey sweetness but it was well balanced with a slight malty flavor.  The aroma was phenominal and it really brought me to higher standards for an ale.
pretty good beer, nothing special.  not sure how this is a STRONG ale with an alcohol content of 5.7.  Just not all that much to talk about, avg. micro brew.
Smells of caramel, bready and chocolate/coffee. Tastes fruity(raisin, apple) a lot of roasted malty bitterness and some hops. Finishes dry bitterish and roasted again. Nice one.

Nice dark amber colour, leaning into black. Plenty of hoppiness in the aromas, even some bread appearing... Quite a powerful taste, leaning towards a stoutiness with plenty of hops. The aftertaste leaves a nice caramel impression.

A nice classic header with a hint of toast/bread. 
A pitch black with a tanned foam.
A medium bitter taste going into a stout-porter direction, very appealing.
A full body with a light creamy texture, soft carbonation, and lightly in fizzynes with a long finish.

Overall a very pleasant and astonishing tasting beer.

(500ml bottle) Clear mahogany body topped by a big rocky beige head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, tobacco/leather, caramel, earthy, light anise.  Taste is medium sweet, tobacco/leather, caramel, earthy, some roast, light anise.  Watery light-medium body.

Poured a brown color with red edges and a very nice head. Lacing was solid. Aroma was of roasted malts, some peat smoke, and coffee. Flavor was similar with some licorice mixed in. Very astringent and finished somewhat bitter and dry, although not that hoppy. Not my personal liking of a beer and Id take many an "English Strong Ale" over it.

Pours to a dark brown, with hints of red, tan head that lingers and excellent lacing. Aroma of malt, and dark fruit. Taste is predominantly dark fruit with hints of choclate at early glass. Alcohol becomes more evident at mid-glass as beer  warms. Slightly sour palate at first turns to a nice smooth, dry warming finish at the end of the glass.
Bottled. Pours deep amber in color. Dark roasted malty aroma. Some roasted coffee notes as well. Bitter roasted malty flavor up front. Some dark fruitiness. Strong roasted bitter finish.

Pours out a clear, dark brown reddish color with a creamy beige head, nice lacing. Aroma was earthy, malty, some bitter chocolate and some roasted coffee bean. Mouthfeel was a turn-off with a harshness that was very unsatisfying in both going down and while swishing around on the palate. Flavors was adequate with bitter chocolate, more earthyness (slightly petey) malty and very dry. The over sweetness made the beer slightly cloying after awhile. Not a beer I will drink again though.

Bottle at Beer on the Pier, Chicago. An English "Strong" ale thats only 5.7%? Nice, rich, molasses aroma. Clear chestnut, mohagany color with decent lace. Lovely color. Initial mouthfeel is a little more American than I would have guessed. Dry, malty. Fairly one dimensional brew, but still pretty good. Too dry.

Bottle, 500ml. A dark amber/brown coloured pour with a large diminishing head. Aromas of malt, toffee and some hops. Somewhat sweet taste of malt and chocolate. A slightly acidic quite bitter finish. Alcohol is noticable but not overpowering. Moderate carbonation. Very nice.
Very dark and very bitter. Lots of hops. The aroma i quite fruity. not crazy about this one.
Pours dark amber with an immense fluffy head.  Nose is of wild honey and embers. Medium body with a bit of a tannic finish.  Taste is quite roasty with a sour note.
Bottle. Nice tannish head with medium duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma is fruity. Taste is fruits and chocolate.

Pours deep burnt orange-red with a large off-white head. Diacetyl and lactose are apparent in the first sniff. A good bit of fruitiness (banana, pear) comes in alongside some roasted, chocolaty notes on the second. The flavor starts with that banana fruitiness followed by a surprisingly strong earthy hoppiness. Finishes pleasantly bitter. I find it difficult, however, to get past the remarkably British banana and diacetyl beginning.

A brown ale with abundant ice cream float head. Hoppiness and malty character and complexity, some cocoa. Earthy, touch herbal, bit astringent mouthfeel, which is fine with food.Lace in glass. Definite nuttiness. Surprisingly drinkable. Satisfying. Good for its style.
brown colored with beige head.  chocolate aroma with deep malt flavor.  medium bodied.
malt and wine aroma.  brownish ruby with a  small off white head.  smoked peat, dark chocolate, and malt flavor.  dry and bitter palate.  hop finish.

Solid, tasty, toffee ale. Malty, slightly dry taste with a sweet aftertaste. Strikingly harsh from the bottle compared to the cask, though this is more of an interesting variation than a bad thing. Be sure to serve at the correct temperature; this ale is particularly sensitive.
500 ml bottle: Medium-bown with big creamy head. Yeasty nose. Toffee english ale.  Malty with little bitterness.  Very smooth.
Pours a nice dark reddish brown color.  Aromas of caramel, butterscotch, tobacco, and hint of coffee.  Flavor is big roasty malts and then a nice blast of hops to finish with.
A dark brown beer with a strong creamy white head. A citrusy aroma  with dry hop undertones. A malty taste, dry hops again and a slightly sweet finish of caramel. (Bottle).
In the bottle at the Royal Mile during the 2006 Crescent Moon Beer Bus Trip. Pours a dark brown with a white head. A very solid tasty beer. Aroma of chocolate and berries. Delicious.

500 ml bottle. Well, another day made progressively lousier with the passage of time, lets see if this can brighten things up before bedtime. Nice beery smell upon opening, pours a nice ruby to brown with some cloudiness under a frothy head. Dont know where those bananas are they refer to, I just get a nice decent English ale feel, with the foam leaving a cola texture on my lips. Okay, some slight fruitness further down, and a solid caramel malt profile with some distinguishing English hops. In fact, Im getting a bit of spicy hop aftertaste. In fact, the hops really come up front near the end, and thats new for something outside the pale ale cetegory, sez I. As a strong ale, it holds it alcohol well.

Bottle into Duvel tulip.  Golden brown with ruby glow in the glass; almost perfectly clear.  Nice large head of fluffy, creamy-looking ecru foam with some nice retention (lasts for a long time before diminishing to a thick dusting).  Lace is very sticky and leaves a fragile pattern about an inch up the side.  "Racing" is deep, thick and slow.  Smell: piney hops sting, dark grains, butter, sweaty socks, steamy bathroom, and dust; a weird blend of appetizing with not-so-much.  Mouthfeel is very creamy, especially in the finish, which is buttery, bready, slightly banana and softly sweet (like lactose) over an incredibly subtle dry hoppiness that is mostly minty in character (with some "stale" coffee grounds in there, although better than that sounds); it lingers on the sides of the tongue after the bready flavor is gone.  Before the finish, the beer is a bit watery and the hops are metallic and thin; the malts lack character, lending only a flaccid sweetness in addition to their straightforward creamy, buttery banana taste.  If only the beginning could be as good as the finish, this would be a pretty good beer.
Smokey malt hop aroma. Dark brown clear colour with good head and lacing. Bitter malt smokey flavour. Fizzy palate.

Feb. 23, 2006; 1 pt. .9 fl. oz. bottle

What news of the North? Foamy & dark, dark amber pour, thick persistent head, much lacing.  Aroma of freshly-cut corn silage; slightly watery mouthfeel with cool blast of fruity caramel malt notes.  Pleasant brew overall.

Purs a dark mahogony red, with an enticing smell.  Lacing on the glass is evident with the head melting away.  First taste has a thin feeling liquid and a sharp hops with a small hint of fruit.  I have had this bottle in the fridge for 8 months and wonder if the length of storage is weighing on the flavor.
Aroma is reasonably bitter, with quite a bit of hops, malt character kicks in as it warms. Taste is similar, with caramel going to honey coming off the malts. Quite nice.
12 Feb 06 - LIght sweet smokey malt aroma.  Clear medium brown colour, reasonable head and suds lacing. Roasted malt and some fruit flavours.  Fizzy finish with a roast malt aftertaste.

Huge offwhite fine-laced head over dark red body. Faint, sweet, roasty aroma with hop notes. Deep, sweet, harmonic taste of roasty malts with red fruit character and bitter, tarry aftertaste with sweet chocolatey taste lingering. Complex and interesting. This is a great beer!
